quote: -- walls of fire on one side,    rivers of lava on the other... we    snaked our way through the hot,    smoldering canyon, our skin so    parched and blistered it was thick    as armor. Kang, Koloth and I had    set out with forty legions and    now, only we three remained to    face T'nag's army.
You know what I like about Klingon    stories, Commander?
Nothing. Lots of people die and    nobody makes any profit.

Chanting a battle cry -- Koloth    attacked their flank -- his eyes    bulging with hate and revenge. It    was a magnificent sight. A    disruptor in one hand, his    Bat'leth in the other -- I saw him    kill two dozen men.
Do you believe a word of this?
Walking along rivers of lava...    walls of fire? Not likely.
And three against an army? Even    more unlikely.
Yeah, but who cares? He tells it    well.
Kang took the high ground -- and    keeping the three suns to his    back, he forced the enemy to    battle him against the blinding    light.
When Kang told this story, you    took the high ground.
Who gets the credit is not    important.

What matters is that in the end,    the mountainside was so covered    with dead that not a square meter    of ground could be seen. We found    T'nag's body by the river, its    waters red with blood. Which one    of us had slain him, none could    say for certain...
So we cut out his heart -- and the    three of us feasted on it   together!
Big heart.
You need more bloodwine.
Thanks -- but I've had enough to    last me a year. I need some tea.
Mister Worf -- I didn't see you    come in.
I was just leaving.
Why don't you join us? I'll    introduce you to Kor.
No.        It might make the Dahar Master...    uncomfortable. I am considered an    outcast by most Klingons.
Kor is not like most Klingons.        Kor!
I'd like you to meet our strategic    operations officer, Commander    Worf.
Ah, Worf the traitor. The pariah.    The lowest of the low...
Pleasure to meet you. Any enemy    of Gowron and the High Council is    a friend of mine.
This is a great honor.
No doubt.
Worf is a great admirer of yours.
I've heard stories about you since    I was a child. Your confrontation    with Kirk on Organia, your attack    on Romulus, your defense of the    Korma Pass --
Everything I've done pales in    comparison to what I'm about to    achieve.
I'm on a quest... a quest for the    most revered icon in Klingon    history.
Kor...
(caught up in the     moment)    An icon that predates the Klingon    Empire, an icon more sacred than    the Torch of G'boj --
Kor...
More revered than Sabak's armor,    and more coveted than the    Emperor's crown!
The Sword of Kahless.
You told me not to tell anybody.
He guessed!        I know where the Sword rests.    Imagine the glory!
The honor of finding the Bat'leth    of the first Warrior King...
Lost for a millennium... It's    return would change Klingon    history. If you know where it is    we must bring it back to the    Emperor.
We?
It would be an honor to accompany    you.        If you'll have me.
We could use another strong arm...
(slapping him on the    back)   And a stout heart. Besides, it   will annoy Gowron.
Returning the Sword to our    people... I would give my life to    do that.
Children will sing our names for    a thousand years! They'll erect    statues of us in the Hall of    Heroes.
Before you decide on a pose for    that statue -- we have to find the   Sword. What makes you so sure you    know where it is?
This.
You see?
See what?
The imprint on the cloth --
Yes!    (touching it     reverentially)    This held the Sword of Kahless.
Don't be so sure... you could    carpet this station with all the    "authentic" Shrouds of the Sword    people have tried to peddle.
No one tried to peddle this -- it    was given to me.
By whom?
I'll tell you everything, later.    Now, I need you to confirm its    authenticity.
I'll look this over in the lab --    first thing in the morning.
Why not right now?
My head is swimming in bloodwine.   Right now --
I'm going to bed. And so should    you.
Absolutely. After I finish what's    left in my cup.
Maj ram, blood brother. (Good   Night)
Maj ram.
Imagine Gowron's face when we    present the sword to the    Emperor...
Kor
Open your mind...
What?
Couldn't find the bed?
Damn that Ferengi and his    replicated bloodwine.
Worf looked a little bleary-eyed    this morning in Ops... how late    did you keep him up?
Until that toad-faced Ferengi    threw us out of his bar.
And then where did you go?
Worf's quarters, I think...        That's right -- he had a bottle of    Yridian brandy he was saving for    a special occasion.
Like meeting you.
He was honored to join our quest.
That is... if there's going to be    a quest. What did you find?

I found both Klingon and Hur'q DNA    on the cloth...        And traces of metallic compounds    that could only have been left...    by a Klingon Bat'leth... a    Bat'leth fourteen hundred years    old.
The time of Kahless! I never    doubted it. When do we leave?
After I talk to Captain Sisko, and    after you answer a few questions.        Now, where did you get this?
The Gamma Quadrant.

A Vulcan geological survey team    was mining bakrinium on an    uncharted planet when they    accidentally unearthed some    ancient ruins. They brought back    several artifacts to study,    including the cloth.
Kor was the Klingon ambassador to    Vulcan.
When he saw the cloth, Kor    recognized the markings and got    them to give it to him as a gift.    They didn't realize it, but the    markings were Hur'q.
Hur'q... that's the Klingon word    for "outsiders," isn't it?

The Hur'q invaded our homeworld    over a thousand years ago. What    they could not pillage, they    destroyed. They took the Sword    and my people have been looking    for it ever since. It is said    that the recovery of the Sword    will bring a new era of glory to    the Klingon Empire. With the    Sword, the Emperor will be able to    unite our people again.
And if two Starfleet officers were    involved in recovering the   Sword... that might go a long way    toward patching things up between    us and the Klingons.
That is my hope as well, Captain.
What about you, old man? Going   along for the adventure?
Hard to resist a good quest.
I suppose you'll want a runabout?
The Mekong's available...
Try to bring it back in one piece.
We'll do our best.
Thanks, Benjamin.
Final systems check is complete.       Where's Kor?
Something tells me he made an    unscheduled stop at Quark's.
To get supplies.
Bloodwine.
And it's not replicated.
Mister Worf, stand by to get    underway.
Thrusters, on-line.
A fast ship, good company, and    great purpose... feels like old    times.
Mister Worf, set a course for the    wormhole.
Course laid in.
Ahead half --
Wait.
Let this moment be remembered.   For on this day, we three --
-- Kor, Dahar Master of the    Klingons, Jadzia Dax, a joined    Trill of seven lives, and Worf,    son of Mogh and thorn in Gowron's    side --
-- together stepped forth into the    eye of destiny.
Now?
Now.
Ahead half thrusters.
Glorious.
Forgive me, commander.
It's a little crowded in here...
I would use the aft quarters for    my exercises but the Dahar Master   is resting.
I know -- I heard him snoring    through the bulkhead.
Commander, I want to thank you for   introducing me to Kor. I'm    honored to be here.
And I'm glad he invited you. Even    if it does make things a little crowded.

Ahh. Slept like an Alvanian cave    sloth. I had a magnificent dream.    I dreamt the three of us were in    the Hall of Heroes presenting the    Bat'leth to the Emperor. We stood    near the statues of Kang and    Koloth... and as the crowd sang    our names, the most astonishing    thing happened... their statues    came to life! Kang and Koloth    were flesh and blood again, and we    held the Sword high... the crowd's    song was so vibrant and thunderous    it ripped open the great dome and    the heavens poured in their light,    and then...
You woke up.

No... a ship uncloaked above --   Kang's ship, the K'tanco... and a    swirl of song lifted Kang, Koloth    and me up into its warm embrace...    and then the ship streaked away    into the golden light.
And Dax and I stayed behind?
Don't you see? It was taking me    to Sto-Vo-Kor -- to join Kang and    Koloth in the afterlife.
Then it's a good thing we didn't    come.
You and Worf have many great deeds    still ahead of you.        But this will be my final quest.
You said that last time.
So I did.        But this deed will assure me a    place in the Hall of Heroes. And    then, I will stand where I    belong... Kang, Koloth and Kor,    together again...
We have assumed a standard orbit.
I'm reading a series of    interconnected structures and    tunnels several kilometers below    the surface.
All that remains of the Hur'q...    the great plunderers of the    galaxy. And now, it is time for    us to reclaim what is ours...
Assuming we can find where to    look. It's a big planet.
The Vulcan survey team was    meticulous -- they mapped the    entire area during their mining    operation.
The Sword should be in the chamber    that was once their Central Museum --   along with all the other great    treasures the Hur'q looted. It's    the structure furthest north.
There's a forcefield around that   chamber.
I know -- the Vulcans told me they   couldn't get through it.       We'll be the first ones inside.
Why didn't you mention this   forcefield before?
It's not important.  I know you'll   find a way past it.
We should be just outside the    forcefield.
Then the Central Chamber is   somewhere back there.
Let's get to work.
First we have to modulate the   field destabilizers to create an    interference pattern.
It's not working...
Try reversing the polarity.
That helped...        Now if we just increase the    amplitude of the interference    field...
Well done, my friends.
The air --
Foul, isn't it? This place has    been undisturbed for hundreds of    years.
The Vulcans may not have gotten in    here -- but someone did.
I'm sorry, Kor.
Don't be sorry for me -- be sorry    for the Empire.
If we can determine who did this --   perhaps we can track them down.
For all we know, the Sword is     halfway across the galaxy by now.
Sounds like a worthy quest.
For you and Worf, perhaps.       But not for me.
My last chance for glory dies here.
Commander --
The dust does not reach the wall.
Something must be repelling it.        I'm getting a faint electrostatic    charge along this section.
Another forcefield?
Disguised by a holographic    projection.
Are you saying there may be    another chamber behind it?
If there is, I'm not sure how we    can get to it. This shield has    completely different harmonics    than the one at the entrance.
Over here.        It's some kind of sensor...    focused on the area just in front    of the forcefield.
It must be keyed to read lifesigns.
Why?
So that only Hur'q could enter.
If you're right... we'll need a    Hur'q tour guide to get us    through.
It may be possible to fool the    sensor into thinking we're Hur'q.
We could reconfigure the tricorder    to emit Hur'q lifesigns.
Exactly.
I still have the DNA readings we    got from the cloth.
I feel like a Hur'q already.
For a thousand years, our people    have waited for this moment...
The age... the composition... the    design... everything's right.
How could you doubt it? Look at    it!
It is more beautiful than I ever    imagined.        You should be the first to hold    it.
How does it feel?
Good. Very, very good. To    think... Kahless himself held    this Bat'leth...
And with it he slew Molor...    conquered the Fek'Ihri and forged    the first Empire. And now... I    hold it in my hands...
We should go. The field    destabilizers won't hold much    longer.
Well, Kor... it seems you were    right. You did find the Sword.
Who are you?
Ask your friend.
He is Toral, from the House of    Duras.
It's good to see you too, Worf.

Seems you were too drunk to    remember me... or the tavern on    Torna Four? You held us all    spellbound with a tale about a    Hur'q cloth and how it was going    to lead you to the Sword.        I was so intrigued I sent my    friend here to see what else you    knew.
What do you want?
What we all want. The Sword.
The Sword is for the Emperor.
Who will be so grateful he'll give   Kor his statue...       ... and perhaps even forgive your    dishonor?
I'm afraid I have different plans    for the Sword.
You think that if you give it to    the Emperor, he'll restore your    family's seat on the High Council.

I'm not giving the Emperor    anything. With the Sword in my    hand, I'll be leading the Empire.       I can see from your face that you    regret having spared my life,    Worf.       Now give it to me.
No.
Then I'm afraid we'll have to take    it.
If he wants it.        Give it to him.
Let's go!
We have to stop the bleeding.    We'd better get you back to the    ship.        Dax to Mekong.
Computer. Three to beam up.
That's a Klingon jamming signal.
Can we override it?
Maybe from the surface.
Kor, make sure we're not being    followed.
Did you see the face of the    Klingon I killed? It was as if he    understood the honor bestowed upon    him. The first man in a thousand    years to die by the Sword of    Kahless.
I'm sure he was very proud.
We should keep moving. Toral will    find a way past the forcefield.
What did Toral mean when he said    you spared his life?
When it was discovered that the    House of Duras had conspired to    destroy my father's honor, Gowron    offered me Toral's life.
Under the Right of Vengeance.
I declined.
Why?
He was a boy. He had done    nothing.
That's beside the point -- it was    a matter of honor.
It was Worf's right to decline.
It was a mistake -- perhaps it's    true what they say about you...    you've been around humans too    long.
Kor --
If he hadn't spared Toral's life,    we'd be on our way to Kronos.
If you hadn't gotten drunk and    told a tavernful of people what    you were planning, Toral wouldn't    have followed us here in the first    place.
I told them nothing of    consequence! How could I know    Toral would send a Lethean to    steal my thoughts.
You should've been more discreet.
And you should've been more of a    Klingon!
Kor... what was that all about?
What?
Worf admires you. You have no    idea how much it meant to him to    be asked along on this journey.
Tell me, Dax... how well do you    know him?
Well enough. Why?

I'm beginning to think I was too    lenient in my judgment of him. A    Klingon who denies himself the    Right of Vengeance is no Klingon    at all.        He dishonors the Sword with his    presence. I don't trust him. I    should have left him on that space    station where he belongs.
Worf... over there.
Bo'taDaH!
HoH!
Lunch!
Delicious, isn't it?
A hunt builds the appetite.
This is disgusting.
But it'll make a good part of the    story.
How we slew the beast. Remember --    it attacked us from the dark, five    meters long --
Ten, at least!
Eyes ablaze, fangs like daggers --
Breathing great plumes of fire.
It seems the son of Mogh is not    amused.
A true warrior has no need to    exaggerate his feats.
You'd better hope I exaggerate or    when they sing songs about this    quest, your verse will say "And    Worf came along."
This is the Sword of Kahless --   not something to shovel food into    your mouth!
It must be treated with honor.

Look at him... he's like the    Hur'q, he thinks it's a museum    piece. Why, Kahless himself used    it to skin the serpent of Xol, to    harvest his father's field, and to    carve a statue for his beloved.         It's a sword.  But Worf doesn't    know what to do with it, except    bow in front of it, and then hand    it over to his precious Emperor.
When we do, you'll get your    precious statue. And after    they've sung songs about you and    you've passed out from drink --   the Emperor will use the Sword to    unite our people.
If Gowron allows him to. The    Emperor is nothing but his puppet.
The Emperor is no one's puppet --    he condemned Gowron's invasion of    Cardassia..
And the invasion went ahead    despite his objection.
That is why the Emperor needs the    Sword. It will allow him to unify    the Houses against Gowron.
The Emperor is a pretender! He's    a clone of the original Kahless    cooked up in a vat by ambitious    clerics. And if you hadn't    supported him, he'd be back in    that vat where he came from!
I supported him because we need    him. He can unite us!

The Sword will unite us -- but   only if it's in the hands of a   true Klingon. Not a politician   like Gowron or a toothless   figurehead like the Emperor... the   Sword must rest in the hands of   someone hardened by battle... pure   of heart... someone who   understands loyalty, honor... a   warrior like Kang -- or Koloth!
Someone like you?
The Empire could do far worse.
We should get moving.
Are you saying that it's your    intention to lead the Empire?
I'm saying... it's my intention to    lead us to the surface.
We need to change your bandage.
We must keep moving.
You're hemorrhaging. We have to    stop the bleeding.
That cave-rat was all bones. I    need another one.
Find a nice fat one. We could all    use something to eat.
Kor never answered my question    about his plans for the sword.
I noticed.
He is a hero to many. If he   returns to Kronos with it and    decides to seize power, many will    follow him.
But you wouldn't?
He is not all that I thought he    was.
Maybe not. But I've known him a    long time -- his heart's in the    right place.

He drinks too much... exaggerates    his feats and blames others for    his own mistakes.         But he could be right about one    thing... the Emperor may be too    weak to stand against Gowron...    even with the Sword.
I thought you believed in the    Emperor.
I don't know what I believe    anymore...
All I know is that when Kor asked    me to help find the Sword -- I    knew we would succeed. I knew we    would find it!
I can't say I felt the same way.
I had no doubts. I felt as if my    whole life was finally coming into    focus...
What do you mean?

For as long as I can remember,    I've been an outsider... I was    raised by humans, but I was too    Klingon to be one of them. I did    not belong. I begged my foster    parents to let me visit the    Klingon homeworld... They arranged    for me to stay with my cousin's    family. When I first set eyes on    the Great Domes of Kronos, I felt    that I'd finally come home... but    my own cousins wanted nothing to    do with me...
You were too human to be one of    them...

I ran away -- into the mountains.    I had no food or water for three    days... but there, in the caves of    No'Mat, Kahless came to me in a    vision. He told me I would do    something no other Klingon had    ever done. After I returned to    Earth, I pondered the meaning of    his words... and wondered what    lay ahead for me. When I was old    enough, I joined Starfleet...
Something no Klingon had ever    done.
And for a time, I thought I had    fulfilled my destiny.

But I now see that Kahless had    something else in mind for me...    something greater... that's why I    had to endure so much pain, why I    was forced to choose between the    Federation and my own people -- I    was being tested... prepared for    some greater purpose...
Like finding the Sword...
More than that.
When I held the Sword in my    hands... I knew the spirit of    Kahless himself had guided me to    it. Don't you see? He wants me    to have it. He wants me to lead    his people!
You sound like Kor.
Kor is an old man. His greatest    days are behind him -- mine are    still ahead.
Then we have a bit of a problem...    there's only one Sword and you    both want it.
How much farther?
The way these caves wind around,    this could take forever.
Or longer.
We can't get across. We'll go    back and find another way up.
Wait.       There --
Kor -- there's a ledge right below   you.
I don't see it.
It's less than a meter down -- let   go and you'll land on it.
Dax -- do you see it?
I can't see anything.
I can't hold you! You have to let   go.
There's no ledge...
It's there.
Then you let go.
No! We cannot risk losing the   Sword!
Let go!
I'll take the Sword to my grave   before I give it to you.
Just hang on -- we'll pull you up.
You call that a ledge?
It would've been sufficient.
For a Degebian mountain goat, not   a Klingon warrior.
You were going to let me fall.
You wanted me to die... so you   could have the Sword for yourself.
And you were willing to take it to   your death -- and rob our people   of their future.
Give it to me!
That's enough, both of you.
I will not give him the Sword.
Then give it to me. I'll carry   it.
Kor, put that dagger away...
Are you siding with him?
Put it away so he can give me the   Bat'leth.
You see. I was right. He's not    to be trusted.
His mind has been poisoned by    bloodwine and age.
He was right about one thing...    You wanted him to fall.        That ledge wouldn't have supported    him. And you knew it.
I did not force him off that    cliff. He is old and clumsy. If    he'd fallen, it would've been his    own fault.
I'm exhausted.
We can rest here for a few hours.
I'm so tired I might even be able    to get some sleep.
I'll stand watch.
How generous of you. We'll just    curl up like trusting children    under your vigilant gaze.
Sleep or don't sleep -- it makes    no difference to me.
You're wounded... I should take    the first watch. You get some    rest. You close your eyes...
I'm not tired.
I understand. It's hard to sleep   in the presence of something so    magnificent. Someone might try to    steal it.
You reveal your own intentions.
Enough! I have the Sword. And    it's not going anywhere.
What was that?
I heard nothing.
A voice.       I hear it again. It's... the   Spirit of Kahless.
He's talking to you, Worf... he's    telling you to bide your time...    let them sleep... then slit their    throats and claim your destiny.
I've had enough of your drunken    ramblings, old man.
And I've had enough of both of    you. I don't care if you sleep or    not -- but I'm going to. So keep    quiet.
Go ahead and sleep, Dax. I'll    keep an eye on him.
Enough!
What?
His eyes! He's been staring at me    for three hours.
And what've you seen reflected in    my eyes? Your own guilt, gnawing    at you.
All right, if you're not going to    sleep, let's walk.
I'm not going anywhere with that    traitorous p'tak.
This ends here.
Agreed.
I'm not going to stand here and    watch you two kill each other.
Stay out of this!
This is between us. We'll settle    it our own way...
MaH HIv DaH!
He's going to get killed.
No... he has the Sword.
HIv DaH!
Qapla'!
Commander!
Worf --
Stop!
I knew in the end, you'd choose    me. We're blood brothers, we've    been through --
Be quiet.
Now, about that jamming device    you're using to block our    communications...
Are you sure about this, Worf?
Yes. It's the only way.
Do we have the right? The Sword    belongs to all Klingons.
But are we ready for it? The    Sword turned you and me against    each other -- imagine how it would    divide the Empire.
Just let me hold it one last time.
No. The Sword is not meant for    us...        It was never our destiny to find    it.
You're wrong. It was our destiny    to find it. It just wasn't our destiny to keep it.
It's done.
Good. It's for the best.
I hope you're right.
It could be lost for another    thousand years.
When it's destined to be found...    it will be.
